dt: {bc}a power-driven mechanism that supplements a primary control operated by a comparatively feeble force (as in a {a_link|servomechanism})

et: borrowed from French {it}servo-moteur,{/it} from Latin {it}servus{/it} "slave" + French {it}-o-{/it} {et_link|-o-|-o-} + {it}moteur{/it} {et_link|motor:1|motor:1} {ma}{mat|serve:1|}{/ma}

The term was apparently the coinage of the French engineer and inventor Joseph Farcot (1824-1908), who introduced such a mechanism in the 1860's. In the publication {it}Le servo-moteur ou moteur asservi{/it} (Paris, 1873), Farcot states "Nous avons cru qu'il était nécessaire de donner un nom nouveau et caractéristique à cet engin nouveau et l'avons appelé servo-moteur ou moteur asservi" (p. 4). ("We thought that it was necessary to give a new and distinguishing name to this new engine, and we have called it 'servo-motor' or 'subjugated motor.'")
shortdef: a power-driven mechanism that supplements a primary control operated by a comparatively feeble force (as in a servomechanism)
